clinical_study.brief_title: High Frequency and Intensive Prevention Program
clinical_study.official_title: High Frequency and Intensive Prevention Program for Cognitive Stabilization and Improving of Quality of Life in Parkinson's Disease Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The treatment of PD has made considerable advances in recent years with respect to drug therapies, as well as many new physiotherapy and drug-based methods, and there have also been great improvements in therapy thanks to deep brain stimulation. Cognitive rehabilitation has shown to be effective in PD (Abbruzzese et al., 2016), however, there has yet to be a major breakthrough in the treatment and prevention of PDD (Parkinson's Disease Dementia ). This is where the high frequency and intensive prevention described here comes into play.

detailed_description.textblock:
Cognitive decline is an important and common complication in Parkinson's Disease (PD); approximately 27% of non-demented PD patients have Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) (Litvan et al. 2012, Chaudhuri et al., 2011) and up to 80% develop PD dementia (PD-D) over the long term (Hely et al., 2005). Cognitive course in PD is heterogeneous and affects visuospatial, attentional, executive and memory function; studies report different cognitive subtypes and divergent patterns of cognitive decline (Kehagia et al., 2010; Litvan et al., 2011; Williams-Gray et al., 2007; Yarnall et al., 2014). Recently, models have been constructed to estimate individual risk for global cognitive impairment using a small set of predictor variables (Liu et al. 2017; Velseboer et al., 2016). These prediction algorithms were developed in large samples of PD patients and accurately forecast cognitive decline in both, patients with MCI and patients with PD-D and were successfully replicated in independent samples; a score with a predefined cut off point predicts dementia with high positive and negative predictive values (Liu et al., 2017).
The primary aim of this study is the possible stabilization or delay of cognitive decline as well as the improvement of the quality of life of the patients. As secondary outcome, the change in symptoms associated with PD, will be investigated. Psychological states as depression and anxiety, as well as cognitive performance in different areas, for example attention and memory shall be investigated. Neurological symptoms, for example motor function and sleepiness, will also be assessed as secondary parameters and potentially confounding factors.
This study is a 4 week randomized controlled trial (RCT) with one experimental intervention group and one control group (Stepped-wedge trial). Primary and secondary outcome measures are assessed at baseline and are repeated after the 4-week intervention period and at 6 month in a follow-up assessment. After 4 weeks there is an intermediate measurement consisting of the primary outcome measures.
The intervention group receives individualized program: the program will be tailored to the patient's needs, strengths and weaknesses, resulting from the initial assessment.
The intervention group receives individualized program: the program will be tailored to the patient's needs, strengths and weaknesses, resulting from the initial assessment.
1. Goal management training (Ariane Giguere-Rancourt et al., 2018) - is a home-based approach for PD patients with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). The program will applied to High Risk Patients for PDD. This well-validated cognitive training is developed to improve executive functions. It helps patients to raise awareness of deficits and improve cognitive control in goal-directed behaviors. Each session last 75-90 minutes, one per week.
2. Physiotherapy - The role of physiotherapy is to maximize functional ability and minimize secondary complications through movement rehabilitation within a context of education and support for the whole person. The overall aim is to optimize independence, safety and well-being, thereby enhancing quality of life (Claire L Tomlinson et al., 2014).
Physiotherapists train patients for example in cueing strategies to improve gait, strength to improve balance, motor co-ordination to improve posture and compensatory movement strategies to improve transfers (Samyra H.J. et al., 2004) The therapy sessions are individually guided by a physiotherapist and/or well-trained voluntarists at University Hospital of Basel (CH). Each session lasts 30 min, 1 to 3 per week.
3. Rhythmic Music Gymnastic - Music makes it easier for patients with PD to improve the sense of rhythm disturbed by the disease. Just listening to loud and rhythmic music leads to a measurable improvement in agility.
In cooperation of music- und physiotherapy Beelitz music-gymnastics 1+2 has been developed: training schemes with music for a daily training program. The music has been composed in accordance with the Patterned Sensory Enhancement. Tune, chords and rhythm "depict" the movement in sound. By this movement and motivation are improved. (3) Each session lasts 60 min, 1 to 3 times a week.
4. Speech therapy -PD affects also face muscles, muscles in mouth and throat that are used to speak. This may cause a person's voice to change, as well as dysarthria, or difficulty in speaking, and dysphagia, or difficulty in swallowing.
These problems may be referred to a speech and language therapist who is trained in all forms of communication, including non-verbal communication such as facial expressions or body language. Such therapists can teach techniques and offer tips for better communication. Each session lasts 60 min, 1 to 3 times a week.
Control-group will obtain best medical treatment (Stepped-wedge trial).

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in in Mini Mental Status (MMS; Folstein et al., 1975)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: This is a widely used procedure, which is referred to as the screening of cognitive deficits. The test includes 22 tasks that are performed as an interview with the patient. A sum value is formed over the 22 tasks; the higher the sum, the better the cognitive function is assessed. From a total value of < 24/30 points, there is a suspicion of a significant cognitive disorder.

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA; Nasreddine et al., 2005)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA; Nasreddine et al., 2005) can be used as an alternative to MMS as a cognitive screening procedure. This measuring instrument was developed because the executive functions are only insufficiently reflected in the MMS. The MoCA is therefore more sensitive than the MMS to cognitive disorders associated with frontal disorders (Lessig, Nie, Xu, & Corey- Bloom, 2012). The test is based on 12 tasks over which a sum value is formed. With a total value of < 26/30, there is a suspicion of clinically relevant cognitive deficits.

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in the Semantic (Morris et al., 1989) and the Phonemic (Thurstone, 1948) fluency
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: In both tasks, the subject should list as many words as possible within one minute that meet a certain criterion ( phonetically): as many S words as possible, semantically: as many animals as possible. In both tests, the variable number of correct answers is used as a measure of verbal fluency.

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in the Five-Point Test (Regard, Strauss, & Knapp, 1982)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The design fluency, are examined with the five-point test. The test person is instructed to produce as many different figures (design) as possible during three minutes. For this, a sheet is handed in consisting of 35 squares with five points drawn in each. The task is to connect at least two dots with a straight line. The variable correctly drawn figures flowed as a parameter for the evaluation of the design fluency. Scores are comprised of the number of novel designs as well as the percentage of perseverative errors (Fernandez, Moroni, Carranza, Fabbro, & Lebowitz, 2009)

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in the Trail Making Test (TMT; Reitan, 1958)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: This is a paper pencil test and comprises two subtasks. Part A measures information processing speed, Part B is used to measure cognitive flexibility. In subtask A, numbers must be connected as quickly as possible in ascending order, while in subtask B numbers must be connected as quickly as possible alternately with letters (numbers in ascending order, letters along the alphabet: 1 - A - 2 - B - C, etc.). From this, various parameters can be calculated, including processing time, number of errors and cognitive adaptability independent of information processing speed (ratio processing time part B divided by processing time part A).

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in the Stroop Test (Stroop, 1935)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: This test consists of three passages, which also include different cognitive Measure functions. During the first passages, the test person is presented with a colour chart; the task is to name the colour points as quickly as possible. The processing time is also a measure of the information processing speed. In the second pass, a blackboard is presented on which words are written in certain colours. In round three, the test person should name the colour of the words presented that interfere with the printing colour. In addition to the characteristic value of the processing time per pass, the error susceptibility and the interference susceptibility can also be determined independently of the processing time (processing time pass 3 divided by processing time pass 1).

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in Modified Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (mWCST; Nelson, 1976)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: This test measures cognitive flexibility and the tendency towards perseveration. The test person is asked to assign four target cards, which differ in terms of the three criteria colour, shape and number, to each card according to a self-chosen sorting rule. After six correctly sorted cards, the test person is instructed to change the rule. This process is repeated until all three criteria have been sorted. Four scores are provided: Number of Categories Correct, Number of Perseverative Errors, Number of Total Errors, and Percent of Perseverative Errors.

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in California Verbal Learning Test (CVLT; Delis, Kramer, Ober, & Kaplan, 1987)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: This is a method that tests memory functions, including encoding, retrieval, and recognition processes. The task is to learn in five cycles a shopping list of 16 words assigned to four semantic categories (i.e. beverages, fruits, clothing, tools). As many words as possible should be enumerated after each cycle. The sum of the words stored in the 1-5 cycles is used as the encoding parameter.

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in Digit Span and the Corsi Block Test (Härtig et al., 2000)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: Digit Span und the Corsi Block Test serve to evaluate the verbal and visual working memory. In the Digit Span, a sequence of numbers is presented orally, which is first repeated forwards and later backwards by the test person. The presented sequences become longer and longer. In the Corsi Block, the test person is presented with a board with irregularly arranged cubes. The task is to remember a sequence of tapped cubes and then to tap the cubes in the same sequence or later to follow the path shown in reverse order. Also with this test the difficulty increases, as the offered sequences become increasingly longer. The total score for the Digit Span is the sum of 12 items, ranging from 0 (worst possible result) to 12 (best possible result). The total score for the Corsi Block is the sum of 14 points in forward typing, ranging from 0 (worst score) to 14 (best symptoms) and the sum of 12 points in backward typing from 0 (worst score) to 12 (best symptoms).

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in the 15-item version of the Boston Naming Test (Kaplan et al., 1978)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The BNT is one of the most frequently used tests for determining confrontational picture-naming abilities. The BNT stimuli are line drawings of objects with increasing naming difficulty, ranging from simple, high-frequency vocabulary (tree) to rare words (abacus). This short form contains 15 items. The administration requires a spontaneous responced within a 10-sec period. Scoring counts the number of spontaneously generated correct responses. The total score for the BNT is the sum of three subscales ranging from 0 (worst possible result) to 15 (best possible result).

primary_outcome.measure: Apathy Evaluation Scale (AES; Marin, Biedrzycki, & Firinciogullari, 1991; German version: Lueken et al., 2006)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The scale comprises a total of 18 questions that are answered either by a relative, a caregiver, the attending physician or psychologist, or in the AES-S version by the patient himself. Behavioural, cognitive and emotional aspects of apathy are recorded. A sum value is calculated from the four-step items; a value > 38 indicates the presence of clinically relevant apathy symptoms in patients with PD

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in Beck Depression Inventory (Beck et al. Arch Gen Psychiatry 1961)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The BDI is a self-administered scale of 21 items (scored 0-3) which assesses depression symptoms. The Beck Inventory is one of the most commonly-used scales for depression in PD. Total score for the BDI is the sum of 21 items, ranging from 0 (best possible outcome) to 63 (worst possible symptoms)

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in Beck Angst Inventory (BAI; Ehlers & Margraf, 2007)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: This is a self-assessment questionnaire that measures the severity of somatic, affective, and cognitive symptoms associated with panic attacks and generalized anxiety disorder using 21 items. The items are answered on a four-level Likert scale and a sum value is calculated for all items.Total score for the BaI is the sum of 21 items, ranging from 0 (best possible outcome) to 63 (worst possible symptoms)

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in Parkinson's disease fatigue scale (PFS; Brown, Dittner, Findley, & Wessely, 2005)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: This is a self-evaluation questionnaire, the physical aspects of fatigue and its influence on the everyday functionality and activity. As the questionnaire was only available in English, it was translated into German. An indication of the presence of clinically relevant fatigue is provided by the mean value calculated from the 16 items. A mean value of > 2.95 indicates the presence of fatigue symptoms

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in the PDQ-39
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The PDQ-39 is a quality of life index for PD. It consists of a 39-item questionnaire that asks about the impact of PD on a person's motor function, gait, mood, cognition, and activities of daily living. Patients are asked to indicate the frequency of each event by selecting one of 5 options: never/occasionally/sometimes/often/always or cannot do at all. Total score is ranging from 0 (best possible outcome) to 156 (worst possible result)

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in Barratt-Impulsiveness-Scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The BIS is a 30-item questionnaire measuring trait impulsivity, under the following factors: attentional (attention and cognitive instability), motor (motor and perseverance), and nonplanning (self-control and cognitive complexity) and is the most widely cited instrument for the assessment of impulsiveness The total score for the attention and cognitive instability is the sum of 8 items,ranging from 8 (best possible result) to 32 (worst possible symptoms). The total score for the motor and perseverance is the sum of 11 items, ranging from 11 (best possible result) to 44 (worst possible symptoms); The total score for the self-control and cognitive complexity ranging from 11 (best possible result) to 44 (worst possible symptoms).

primary_outcome.measure: NEO-FFI-30 (Körner et al., 2008)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The individual characteristics measurable by the NEO-FFI are openness to experience, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism. The assignment to the five dimensions mentioned is based on the degree of agreement to the 30 items. Using a five-level rating scale, which for each item is 0 (fully applicable) to 4 (fully inapplicable), the respondent can judge for himself, in how far the item applies to him. The value 2 encodes a neutral response.

primary_outcome.measure: The locus of Control Scale (The IE-4 scale) ( Julian B. Rotter et al., 1966)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: Control beliefs describe the extent to which a person believes he or she can or cannot control what is happening around him or her. The Locus of Control concept of Rotter ( Wallston et al., 1978) distinguishes between two types of control convictions, internal and external. The IE-4 scale consists of two subscales for internal and external control conviction each containing two items (Kovaleva et.,al 2012). The four items are displayed on a scale with a five-step answer Format from "do not agree at all" (1) to "fully agree" (5)

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in AST - Apraxia Screen of TULIA
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The Test to Measure Upper Limb Apraxia (TULIA) is one method of determining upper limb apraxia through the qualitative and quantitative assessment of gesture production. The total score for the AST is the sum of 12 items, ranging from 0 (worst possible result) to 12 (best possible result).

primary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in Rey-Osterrieth complex figure, Copy (Duley et al., 1993)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
primary_outcome.description: The Rey-Osterrieth (ROCF) and Taylor (TCF) complex figure tests are widely used to assess visuospatial and constructional abilities as well as visual/non-verbal Memory (Marie-Pier Tremblay et al., 2015). The score ranging from 0 (worst possible result) to 36 (best possible result). ·

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
secondary_outcome.description: EEG power in Delta; Theta; Alpha 1; Alpha 2; Beta. Brain Network Connectivity

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
secondary_outcome.description: Detecting changes in blood hemoglobin concentrations associated with neural activity

secondary_outcome.measure: The Reliable Change Index in the sum of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part I + UPDRS Part II +UPDRS Part III +UPDRS Part IV
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
secondary_outcome.description: This is the standard scale used for grading severity of PD. (UPDRS) - Four Parts Higher score values represent a worse outcome. Part I: Mentation, Behavior and Mood - 4 questions 1-4 Score range: 1-16; Part II: Activities of Daily Living - 13 questions 5-17 Score range: 0-52 Part III: Motor Examination - 19 questions 18-31 and 25 total assessments Score range: 0-100 Part IV: Complications of Therapy (In the past week) - 11 questions Score range: 0-25

secondary_outcome.measure: Non Motor Symptom Assessment Scale for Parkinson's disease
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
secondary_outcome.description: This is a 30-item rater-based scale to assess a wide range of non-motor symptoms in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD). The NMSS measures the severity and frequency of non-motor symptoms across nine dimensions. The scale can be used for patients at all stages of PD. ranging from 0 (best possible score) to 210 (worst possible symptoms)

secondary_outcome.measure: The SEIQoL-DW ((Schedule for the Evaluation of Individual Quality of Life - Direct Weighting)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after 4 weeks of training, After 6-month
secondary_outcome.description: The SEIQoL-DW questionnaire is the most frequently used measuring device for the evaluation of the individual quality of life of patients. The patient is asked to complete five fields to identify the areas of his/her life that are currently important to his/her quality of life and to briefly explain them. The aim is then to determine the level of satisfaction in each of these areas and five of these areas using a pie chart that can be freely divided by the patient.

arm_group.description: High frequency and intensive prevention program - Goal management training (Ariane Giguere-Rancourt et al., 2018) - is a home-based approach for PD patients with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) Physiotherapy Rhythmic Music Gymnastic Speech therapy

intervention.intervention_name: High frequency and intensive prevention program
intervention.description: This study is a 4 week randomized controlled trial (RCT)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with idiopathic Parkinson syndrome according to United Kingdom Parkinson's Disease Brain Bank Criteria, suffering from high risk of cognitive decline (Liu et al., 2017a) >0.19 or reliable cognitive change (Jacobson & Truax, 1991)
- mental competence to provide informed consent
- able to understand German sufficiently
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe dementia (DMS-IV, mini mental Status (MMS) <24, moca test (MoCa) <21)
- young onset Parkinson's disease (<18y)
- other neurological or psychiatric diseases of the brain not related to PD
- secondary parkinsonism
- physical impairment hindering the adequate execution of the training
- insufficient knowledge of German
- pregnancy
- Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) is no exclusion criterion.
